plants.name: Chrysanthemum indicum
plants.description: Chrysanthemums are popular garden plants known for their vibrant and diverse flower forms. They bloom in late autumn to early winter, bringing color to gardens as many other plants fade.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, especially East Asia and North America
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums were first cultivated in China over 2,500 years ago and symbolize longevity and rejuvenation in many cultures.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: Camellias are evergreen shrubs prized for their large, elegant flowers that bloom in late autumn through winter, especially in mild climates. The blossoms can be single, semi-double, or double and are lush in appearance.
plants.location: Eastern Asia, cultivated in gardens globally
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica is the original species from which many hybrid tea camellias are derived, important in tea culture.

plants.name: Hamelia patens
plants.description: A tropical shrub that blooms almost year-round in warm climates, its fiery red-orange flowers attract hummingbirds and butterflies. In subtropical zones, November marks a peak blooming period.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round, with peaks in late autumn and spring
plants.location: Southern USA, Mexico, Central and South America
plants.funFact: Firebush flowers produce abundant nectar and are a valuable nectar source for pollinators in tropical gardens.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: An Australian native tree that produces bright orange, spider-like flowers attracting nectar-feeding birds. In warmer parts of Australia, it can bloom in late spring and autumn, including November.
plants.location: Eastern Australia and cultivated in similar climates globally
plants.funFact: Despite its name, the Silky Oak is not an oak but a member of the Proteaceae family, famous for unique flower structures.
